taskbody.context: To add an attribute to an element, do the following:

step.cmd: Place the cursor on the element.

info.p: Place the cursor in the element in the Editing Window or click the element in the ContentMap.
info.note: When you point the cursor over an element in the ContentMap, you can see a hint with its attributes.

step.cmd: Call up the Element Attributes Dialog.

info.p: To call up the Element Attributes Dialog (or move the focus to the docked Element Attributes Dialog), do one of the following:

choice.p: Click the Element Attributes button on the toolbar.
Right-click and select Element Attributes from the context menu.

stepresult.p: The Element Attributes Dialog will appear.

note.p: The Element Attributes Dialog is a liquid dialog: it can have a different, docked appearance. For more information about liquid dialogs, see .

step.cmd: In the Element Attributes Dialog, add an attribute:

info.p: To add an attribute, do the following:

substep.cmd: In the Name combo-box, select or type the attribute's name.

note.p: A list of allowed attributes is provided if validation is on.

substep.cmd: In the Value combo-box, select or type the attribute's value.

note.p: To insert a relative file name as the attribute's value, browse for the file using the Browse button .

The meanings of icons are as follows:
This attribute has a default value defined in Schema.
This is a required attribute.
Attribute has a fixed value.
Attribute has ID type.
Attribute has IDREF type.
Attribute has a custom type (Schema data-type).
You can call up help for an attribute.

info.p: To close the Element Attributes Dialog, click the Close button.
